title: The Nuns’ Rules and Their Analysis

pli-tv-bi-vb-pj8.translated_title: 8. The training rule on behaving inappropriately in eight ways
pli-tv-bi-vb-pj8.blurb: A nun who agrees to all of eight kinds of flirtatious behavior is expelled. This is the first among a large number of rules that features the notorious group of six nuns. These nuns were possibly affiliated with the group of six monks, or they are modelled on them.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc5.blurb: A nun who inserts more than two joints of the fingers into the vagina must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc57.blurb: A nun who does not invite correction from both Orders after the rainy season must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pj.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pārājika. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but there is no doubt that it refers to expulsion from the monastic Sangha. There are eight such rules for the nuns, four of which are shared with the monks. Anyone who breaches any of these rules immediately loses her status as a nun. She is expelled from the Sangha and ineligible for re-ordination for the rest of her life. The pārājikas, together with the next category of rules, the saṅghādisesas, are collectively known as serious offenses, garukāpatti. These rules are the most fundamental ones for the proper living of the monastic life.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc34.blurb: A nun who does not attend on a sick monastic disciple must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pd1.translated_title: 1. The training rule on asking for ghee

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc74.translated_title: 74. Giving ordination while under twelve years’ seniority
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc74.blurb: A nun with insufficient seniority who gives ordination must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb.translated_title: The Nuns’ Rules and Their Analysis
pli-tv-bi-vb.blurb: The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the Monastic Code for nuns, the Bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into seven chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter. These units begin with one or more origin stories, which tell the circumstances that led the Buddha to lay down a particular rule. The rule is then stated, followed by a word commentary that analyzes every significant word contained in the rule. After the word commentary follows a permutation series in which a variety of different scenarios are evaluated and offenses assigned as appropriate. At the end comes a non-offense clause, stating important exceptions to the rule, sometimes followed by individual case studies, in which the Buddha decides the offense incurred in ambiguous cases.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc44.blurb: A nun who serves a lay person must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc87.blurb: A nun who wears ornaments must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc18.blurb: A nun who criticizes someone without reflection must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc47.blurb: A nun who uses a communal menstruation robe beyond the intended period must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc40.translated_title: 40. Not wandering after the rainy season
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc40.blurb: A nun who does not go wandering after the rainy season must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-ss10.blurb: A nun who persistently says that she will renounce Buddhism and join another religion is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bi-vb-np1.translated_title: 1. The training rule on collecting almsbowls
pli-tv-bi-vb-np1.blurb: A nun who has more than one bowl must relinquish the extra bowl and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc52.blurb: A nun who abuses a monk must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc39.blurb: A nun who goes wandering during the rainy season must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc15.blurb: A nun who leaves a house without informing the owners must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc60.translated_title: 60. Getting medical treatment from a man
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc60.blurb: A nun who is alone with a man and gets treatment from him on the thigh must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc68.translated_title: 68. Not guiding a disciple after ordination
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc68.blurb: A nun who ordains a student but does not guide her for two years must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc46.blurb: A nun who gives food to anyone who is not a Buddhist monastic must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc8.translated_title: 8. Disposing of waste over a wall
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc8.blurb: A nun who disposes of feces, urine, or rubbish over a wall must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc86.blurb: A nun who wears a hip ornament must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11.translated_title: 11. Accusing nuns of acting from bias
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11.blurb: A nun who persistently says that the other nuns are biased because a legal issue has not been decided to her liking is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bi-vb-as.blurb: There are seven adhikaraṇasamathadhamma, “principles for the settling of legal issues”, which are the same for the nuns and the monks. These are not rules in the ordinary sense and as such fall outside of the classification into serious and light offenses. Instead, they set out the proper methods for dealing with legal issues. The detailed explanation for these is found in the Samathakkhandhaka. The legal issues to be settled through these principles fall into four categories: disputes, accusations, offenses, and proceedings. “Proceedings” includes monastic procedures such as ordination and the keeping of the observance day (uposatha).

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc96.blurb: A nun who enters an inhabited area without a bust cover must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc41.blurb: A nun who goes to see a pleasure house or a pleasure garden must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-ss4.blurb: A nun who, without permission, reinstates another nun who has been legitimately ejected is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc9.blurb: A nun who disposes of feces, urine, or rubbish on cultivated plants must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc23.blurb: A nun who does not sew back together the robe of another nun after unstitching it must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc64.translated_title: 64. Ordaining a trained candidate without approval
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc64.blurb: A nun who ordains a trainee nun without the approval of the Order must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-np2.blurb: A nun who distributes robe-cloth inappropriately must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc84.blurb: A nun who uses a sunshade and sandals must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-sk.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as sekhiya, “involving training”. There are seventy-five such rules, and they are the same both for the monks and the nuns. The sekhiyas are mostly rules of etiquette. Breaking a sekhiya is only considered to be a transgression if the offender is acting out of disrespect for the rule.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc29.blurb: A nun who hinders the distribution of robe-cloth without a proper reason must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc78.translated_title: 78. Not ordaining a trainee who has followed one
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc78.blurb: A nun who promises to ordain a trainee nun in return for being attended on for two years but then makes no effort to get her ordained must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc49.blurb: A nun who studies pointless knowledge must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc45.blurb: A nun who agrees to settle a legal issue but then makes no effort to do so must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc13.translated_title: 13. Meeting a man in the open
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc13.blurb: A nun who, seeking privacy, stands alone with a man out in the open must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc3.blurb: A nun who slaps her genitals must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc32.blurb: A nun who shares bedding with another nun must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc70.translated_title: 70. Not sending away a new disciple
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc70.blurb: A nun who ordains a student without afterwards taking her away must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc42.blurb: A nun who uses a large or luxurious seat must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc7.blurb: A nun who asks for raw grain and then prepares and eats it must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc72.blurb: A nun who ordains an unmarried girl who has not completed her training must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc4.blurb: A nun who uses a dildo must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc12.translated_title: 12. Meeting a man in a concealed place
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc12.blurb: A nun who, seeking privacy, stands alone with a man in a concealed place must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc24.blurb: A nun who leaves any of her five robes untouched for five days must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc79.translated_title: 79. Ordaining one who is difficult to live with
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc79.blurb: A nun who ordains a trainee nun who socializes inappropriately and is difficult to live with must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6.translated_title: 6. Encouraging a nun to receive food from a man with lust
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6.blurb: A nun who encourages another nun to receive food from a lustful man is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pj1-4.translated_title: Rules in common with the monks

pli-tv-bi-vb-np.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as nissaggiya pācittiya, “entailing relinquishment and confession”. There are thirty such rules for the nuns, the same number as for the monks, although only eighteen are held in common. These rules, together with the remaining rules of the Monastic Code, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is usually no penalty apart from confession. For the nissaggiya pācittiyas, however, any item involved in the committing of an offense must be relinquished. Once the offense has been confessed, the item is, with a few exceptions, returned to the offender.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc66.blurb: A nun who ordains a married girl who has not completed her training must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc21.blurb: A nun who bathes naked must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc2.blurb: A nun who removes hair from the armpits or the groin must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc30.translated_title: 30. Blocking the ending of the robe season
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc30.blurb: A nun who inappropriately blocks the Order from ending the robe-making season must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-np11.translated_title: 11. Getting an expensive heavy cloak in exchange
pli-tv-bi-vb-np11.blurb: A nun who asks for an expensive, heavy outer-robe must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-np3.blurb: A nun who takes back a robe given in exchange to another nun must relinquish the robe and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc88.blurb: A nun who bathes with scents and colors must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc17.blurb: A nun who spreads out bedding in a house and then sits or lies down without asking the owners for permission must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5.blurb: A lustful nun who receives food from a lustful man is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc83.translated_title: 83. Ordaining two in the same year
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc83.blurb: A nun who ordains two women in one year must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-np6.blurb: A nun who exchanges away a requisite belonging to the Order that is designated for a specific purpose must relinquish the item and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc67.translated_title: 67. Ordaining a trained married girl without approval
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc67.blurb: A nun who ordains a married girl without the approval of the Order must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc50.blurb: A nun who teaches pointless knowledge must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-np9.translated_title: 9. Exchanging designated collective property that was asked for
pli-tv-bi-vb-np9.blurb: A nun who asks for a collective requisite designated for a specific purpose and then exchanges it for something else must relinquish the item and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20.blurb: A nun who cries and beats herself must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pj5.translated_title: 5. The training rule on physical contact with a man
pli-tv-bi-vb-pj5.blurb: A lustful nun who agrees to a lustful man touching her anywhere below the collar bone and above the knees is expelled.

pli-tv-bi-vb-np10.translated_title: 10. Exchanging designated personal property that was asked for
pli-tv-bi-vb-np10.blurb: A nun who asks for a personal requisite for a specific purpose and then exchanges it for something else must relinquish the item and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc71.translated_title: 71. Ordaining an unmarried woman under twenty
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc71.blurb: A nun who ordains an unmarried girl less than twenty years old must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc62.blurb: A nun who ordains a woman who is breastfeeding must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc89.blurb: A nun who bathes with scents and oil-seed flowers must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc77.translated_title: 77. Not ordaining a trainee after promising
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc77.blurb: A nun who promises to ordain a trainee nun in return for robe-cloth but then makes no effort to get her ordained must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc95.blurb: A nun who asks a monk a question without obtaining leave must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc90.translated_title: 90. Getting a massage from a nun
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc90.blurb: A nun who makes another nun rub her must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc82.blurb: A nun who gives ordination in consecutive years must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc76.translated_title: 76. Agreeing to stop ordaining, but then criticizing it
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc76.blurb: A nun who agrees when she is refused permission to give ordination but later criticizes it must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc91-93.translated_title: 91–93. Getting a massage from a trainee nun … from a novice nun … from a female householder
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc91-93.blurb: A nun who makes a trainee nun, a novice nun, or a laywoman rub her must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc65.translated_title: 65. Ordaining a married girl under twelve
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc65.blurb: A nun who ordains a married girl less than twelve years old must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc48.blurb: A nun who goes wandering without giving up her lodging must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc59.blurb: A nun who does not ask the Order of monks every half-month about the observance day and the going for instruction must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-np5.blurb: A nun who gets one thing from a steward but then exchanges it for something else must relinquish the item and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc75.blurb: A nun who gives ordination without the approval of the Order must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pj6.translated_title: 6. The training rule on concealing an expulsion offense
pli-tv-bi-vb-pj6.blurb: A nun who does not take any action when she knows that another nun has committed an offense entailing expulsion is expelled. This is the first among a large of rules in which the notorious nun Thullanandā was the original offender. Either Thullanandā was an exceptionally bad nun or she is a literary stand-in for the real offenders.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc31.blurb: A nun who lies down on the same bed as another nun must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pj7.translated_title: 7. The training rule on siding with an ejected monk
pli-tv-bi-vb-pj7.blurb: A nun who persistently sides with a monk who has been legitimately ejected is expelled.

pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2.blurb: A nun who ordains a female criminal sentenced to death is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc81.blurb: A nun who ordains a trainee nun after the consent of the Order has expired must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc55.blurb: A nun who tries to keep her supporters from supporting others must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-ss.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as saṅghādisesa. The meaning of the word is disputed, but according to the commentary it means that the Sangha is required at the beginning (ādi) and for the rest (sesa) of the procedure. There are seventeen such rules for the nuns, seven of which are shared with the monks. Offenders must undergo a period of probation before being rehabilitated to their former status in the Sangha.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc11.translated_title: 11. Meeting a man in the dark
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc11.blurb: A nun who, seeking privacy, stands alone with a man at night must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc22.blurb: A nun who makes a bathing robe that is too large must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc26.blurb: A nun who hinders an order of nuns from receiving robe-cloth must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc14.translated_title: 14. Meeting a man on a street
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc14.blurb: A nun who, seeking privacy, stands alone with a man on street must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc33.translated_title: 33. Making a nun ill at ease
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc33.blurb: A nun who intentionally makes another nun ill at ease must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc51.blurb: A nun who enters a monks’ monastery without permission must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1.translated_title: 1. The training rule on eating garlic
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1.blurb: A nun who eats raw garlic must confess the offense. This rule includes the Suvaṇṇahaṁsa Jātaka tale, “the Golden goose Jātaka,” found in slightly different form in the Jātaka collection.

pli-tv-bi-vb-ss12.blurb: Nuns who are persistently notorious for inappropriate socialization, who create difficulties for the Order, and who hide each other offenses are suspended.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc37.blurb: A nun who goes wandering without a group of travelers in a dangerous area of her own country must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc43.blurb: A nun who spins yarn must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc85.blurb: A nun who travels in a vehicle must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc94.blurb: A nun who sits down in front of a monk without asking permission must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc80.blurb: A nun who ordains a trainee nun who has not been given permission by her parents and husband must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54.translated_title: 54. Eating more after refusing an offer
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54.blurb: A nun who eats after finishing her meal must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc28.translated_title: 28. Giving a robe to a non-monastic
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc28.blurb: A nun who gives a robe to anyone who is not a Buddhist monastic must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc56.translated_title: 56. Spending the rainy season apart from monks
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc56.blurb: A nun who spends the rainy season in a monastery without monks must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc10.blurb: A nun who goes to see a show must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-sk1.translated_title: 1. Not wearing the sarong evenly all around

pli-tv-bi-vb-ss1.translated_title: 1. The training rule on taking legal action
pli-tv-bi-vb-ss1.blurb: A nun who uses litigation inappropriately is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc36.blurb: A nun who persistently engages in inappropriate socialization with lay people must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-np8.blurb: A nun who exchanges away a collective requisite designated for a specific purpose must relinquish the item and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc6.blurb: A nun who attends on a monk while he is eating must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc25.blurb: A nun who wears a borrowed robe without the permission of the owner must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pd2-8.translated_title: 2–8. Asking for oil … for honey … for syrup … for fish … for meat … for milk … for curd

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc16.blurb: A nun who sits or lies down on a seat in a house without asking the owners for permission must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3.blurb: A nun who walks alone in an uninhabited area or spends the night by herself is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc27.blurb: A nun who blocks an appropriate distribution of robe-cloth must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pācittiya, “entailing confession”. There are one hundred and sixty-six such rules for the nuns, seventy of which are shared with the monks. This is the largest class of rules in the Monastic Code. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession.

pli-tv-bi-vb-ss13.blurb: A nun who persistently encourages other nuns to act in contravention of the previous rule is to be suspended.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc38.blurb: A nun who goes wandering without a group of travelers in a dangerous area abroad must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-np7.translated_title: 7. Exchanging designated Sangha property that was asked for
pli-tv-bi-vb-np7.blurb: A nun who asks for a requisite belonging to the Order that is designated for a specific purpose and then exchanges it for something else must relinquish the item and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69.blurb: A nun who does not follow her preceptor for two years must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc73.translated_title: 73. Ordaining a trained unmarried woman without approval
pli-tv-bi-vb-pc73.blurb: A nun who ordains an unmarried girl without the approval of the Order must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pd.blurb: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pāṭidesanīya, “entailing acknowledgement”. There are eight such rules for the nuns. These eight rules for the nuns are equivalent to a single rule for the monks (bhikkhu-pācittiya 39). In summary, they say that a nun who asks for special food must acknowledge the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-np12.translated_title: 12. Getting an expensive light cloak in exchange
pli-tv-bi-vb-np12.blurb: A nun who asks for an expensive, light outer-robe must relinquish it and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc63.blurb: A nun who ordains a trainee nun who has not completed her training must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53.blurb: A nun who in anger abuses an order must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc19.blurb: A nun who curses herself or another must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-np4.blurb: A nun who asks for one thing but after receiving it says she wants something else must relinquish the item and confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc35.blurb: A nun who gives a dwelling place to another nun and then throws her out must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc58.blurb: A nun who does not go to the instruction or formal meetings of the Order must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb-pc61.blurb: A nun who ordains a pregnant woman must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bu-vb.translated_title: The Monks’ Rules and Their Analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb.blurb: The Bhikkhu-vibhaṅga or Mahā-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the monks’ rules” or “the great analysis”), or simply the Vibhaṅga for short, contains the Monastic Code for monks, the Bhikkhu-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The Vibhaṅga is divided into eight chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the aniyatas (“the undetermined”) and the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense. Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter. These units begin with one or more origin stories, which tell the circumstances that led the Buddha to lay down a particular rule. The rule is then stated, followed by a word commentary that analyzes every significant word contained in the rule. After the word commentary follows a permutation series in which a variety of different scenarios are evaluated and offenses assigned as appropriate. At the end comes a non-offense clause, stating important exceptions to the rule, sometimes followed by individual case studies, in which the Buddha decides the offense incurred in ambiguous cases.

pli-tv-kd.blurb: The Khandhakas (“the Chapters”) comprise the rules and regulations of both Sanghas that fall outside of the Monastic Code, the Pātimokkha. There are 22 individual Khandhakas, most of which discuss a more or less unified topic. The Khandhakas include a variety of material, such as assorted biographical material of a number of eminent disciples and some notorious ones. They also incorporate a few Jātakas and other tales, as well as the stories of the first communal recitation after the Buddha’s passing away and the famous Vesālī affair, sometimes known as “the second council”. The whole collection is structured around the life of the Buddha after his awakening.
